https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/57764/ : SUCCESS
Redfish Validator?
Done
nitpick: spelling StorageController, a few times in this file
Done
Why?

Since right now we are only using Storage/1/ to manage all the Drives,

Since Storage is basically used as a Drive/StorageController Collections... I thought it is safe to just have a Storage be default to each chassis. This will allow better Storage/Drive managements.

I don't think this scales to other implementations very well.
I feel this is not a very robust solution and isn't what we have done other places. 
 
Do we need new inventory items? A storage inventory item? Do we need to create associations between this new storage inventory item and chassis? 

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/41468 

Can we do the same with Drives? New documented associations and new inventory items if we need?

Yeah, we can add new Storage interface to support this for it to be more robust.

I have the change in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/44540

As for the association between the storage storage inventory item and chassis, I think we can just link to the Storages that is under the Chassis's object path. I think the doc you were referring to are focus more on things that is at a higher level than the current Chassis and cannot be directly under the chassis's object path.

Same thing with Drive. Can't we just use the sub paths to determine the relationships? to the Storage and Chassis.

> As for the association between the storage storage inventory item and chassis, I think we can just link to the Storages that is under the Chassis's object path

> Same thing with Drive. Can't we just use the sub paths to determine the relationships? 

I just want whatever we do here to be consistent e.g. whatever we choose here https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/38570 should match. (there is several other inventory to inventory relationships in review now)

We might need that doc in first setting the direction: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/41468

yeah, I agree that we should be consistent on how we want to approach this.

It seems like the relationship in https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/38570 it not finished yet....

Yeah, sounds like we need to have https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/41468 before any of the inventory relationship changes go in.

I have updated it to follow https://www.snia.org/sites/default/files/technical-work/swordfish/draft/v1.2.2/pdf/Swordfish_v1.2.2_NVMeMappingGuide.pdf#page=17

now.
This link will also be affected depending on the changes that is made to how Storage is makde.
Ack

Going to have to explain this.. 
I think we should look for xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Storage or xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Drive or whatever inventory item(s) would map to Redfish's storage definition. I don't think Board and Chassis should map to Redfish Storage resources. 

"The Storage schema defines a storage subsystem and its respective properties. A storage subsystem represents a set of physical or virtual storage controllers and the resources, such as volumes, that can be accessed from that subsystem."

I just thought it was simple to get chassis/board to have an empty Storage and good to go.

But we can also do some more check for this.

I am not sure if we can just search for `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.Drive` or `xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.StorageController` for this. Since the Drive + StorageController might be linked together by the Storage.

How about we parse the Board/Chassis and search the subpaths for paths that has StorageController or Drive to include it in here. This way... only the ones that actually have a storage subsystem have a link to a storage... 

This also won't affect the Storage implementations.
ok, this should be fine now.

Don't we need to handle resource not found now?

E.g. /redfish/v1/Systems/system/Storage/badStorageId

I believe same above

oh yeah. this will just return an empty output.

I think it should return a member collection pointing to /redfish/v1/Systems/system/Storage/, based on Swordfish spec. E.g.

```
$ curl -u root:0penBmc -X GET http://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Storage
{
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Storage",
  "@odata.type": "#StorageCollection.StorageCollection",
  "Members": [
    {
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/Systems/system/Storage/storage0"
    }
  ],
  "Members@odata.count": 1,
  "Name": "Storage Collection"
}
```


The current one will return 2 resources (/redfish/v1/Storage/ and /redfish/v1/system/Storage/) on the same storage device. 

Refer to Figure 4 in https://www.snia.org/sites/default/files/technical-work/swordfish/draft/v1.2.2/pdf/Swordfish_v1.2.2_NVMeMappingGuide.pdf
Thanks for the feedback. I'll take a closer look on how to model this to match that spec... if we want to do that.
I have updated, PTAL.
Done
There should not be any resource under /redfish/v1/Storage. /redfish/v1/Storage should redirect to /redfish/v1/Systems/{id}/Storage
From the Swordfish spec, it just looks like `/redfish/v1/Storage` can have stuff. but it just link to the `/redfish/v1/Systems/{id}/Storage` directly.
Done
I don't have anything more to add. There are still few comment threads that are still open.

You need to deal with the case that multiple storage devices on the same plugin card (e.g. NVMe expansion card). 

The NVMe storages will share the same EEPROM, meaning the storages belongs to same board/chassis. 

On dbus the device tree will be: 

board_0/nvme_subsys_0/
       /nvme_subsys_1/
board_1/nvme_subsys_0/
       /nvme_subsys_1/

However in the Redfish model, the all storages are flatten into a single StorageCollection, which means you cannot simply use the file name of the path as the collection entries. 

You can do either:
1. use the uuid of the subsys.
2. use the md5 (or other interpretation) of the whole DBUS object path.

I honestly still think that in this case that we should just name it

- board_0_nvme_subsys_0
- board_0_nvme_subsys_1
- board_1_nvme_subsys_0
- board_1_nvme_subsys_1

and such. There will just be some redundant info, but maybe that's fine.

I just feel like if we want to support that use case then it will mess up the case where that is not an issue.

> I honestly still think that in this case that we should just name it


This is the way..... entity manager has handled this for some time.  Naming is entirely within the control of the EM config file for this reason, so you can pick unique, but non-redundant names for a given device that make sense in a debug context for that system.  This behavior has been present in entity-manager for some time, so I would expect that's the path here.
That is the same way I named sensors for nvme daemon, since all sensors on PDI model routed under a single root instead of under individual chassis/boards.

ok, sounds good. Thanks.

I think we will go with that approach to avoid extra complication when it is not needed.
